Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pore Formation Mechanisms in Laser Powder-Bed Fusion Additive Manufacturing: Particle-Resolved Modeling and Fundamental Experimentation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing (AM) has created a new paradigm of integrated materials, design and manufacturing innovations for effective product development and realization across a broad range of industries. Metal AM technologies such as selective laser melting (SLM), which uses a powder-bed and a high power laser, are especially beneficial in making complex-geometry, high-performance components without incurring tooling costs, giving early adopters a competitive advantage in the global market. One of the key challenges that hinder efficient metal AM technology implementation in industry is part quality inconsistency that is significantly affected by porosity in AM parts. Pores, with sizes of one to one hundred microns, are internal defects generated during the process and that cause large variations in part performance. Pore formation in metal AM is complex and not fully understood, making it difficult to predict for quality control. This award corroborates basic research needs of the porosity issue in metal AM parts. The project tackles original research on the coupled multi-scale and multi-physics process of heating, melting and solidification of numerous microscopic metallic particles in SLM. Research findings will not only establish correlations between the process parameters, material properties and pore attributes, but may also lead to novel techniques for mitigating pore defects, and thus, have a potential to accelerate metal AM adoption in U.S. industry. In addition, this project will contribute toward workforce training for metal AM industrial needs and attract high school students into advanced manufacturing technologies.

The objectives of this research are to distinguish pore formation mechanisms in SLM and to theoretically predict, analyze and experimentally characterize the porosity in SLM parts. In this collaborative research between the University of Louisville (UofL) and the University of Alabama (UA), a hybrid numerical modeling technique will be developed for particle-resolved simulations capable of capturing different pore formation mechanisms in SLM. The model will be validated by SLM experiments of small-scale specimen fabrications, incorporating an infrared thermal imager for process temperature and melt-pool dynamics. The fabricated specimens will be measured using micro-scale x-ray computed-tomography and analyzed to attain statistical data of detailed porosity attributes for comparison with the results from numerical modeling. The research efforts will be extended to study the relationship between process parameters and morphology and distribution of porosity in SLM, and to estimate process windows that minimize pore defects. If successful, this study will distill knowledge of a convoluted multi-physics phenomenon and will offer significant insight detailing the key to particular mechanisms of different pore formations. The research results will be included in the training materials for the Additive Manufacturing Competency Center on the University of Louisville campus, providing practitioners of the SLM technology with better understanding of the relationship between processing parameters, porosity formation, and mechanical properties of critical AM-fabricated components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is devoted to the development of a hybrid numerical technique for particle-resolved simulations of the selective laser melting (SLM) process of metal powders and bulk targets based on smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) and application of this technique for theoretical investigation of various pore formation mechanisms in SLM.

The key outcome of the project is a three-dimensional computational model and corresponding computer code that account for of all major heat and mass transfer processes in SLM of metal powders. This model includes (1) a multi-phase SPH-based computational model that describes melting and solidification processes, as well hydrodynamics and heat transfer in the molten material flow; (2) ray tracing (RT) approach for modeling of laser radiation propagation and absorption, (3) kinetic model of vapor flow in a background gas, which is implemented in the form of the direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method, and (4) trajectory solver for powder particles. The SPH code for the molten material flow accounts for the recoil and cooling effects of evaporation, as well as the Marangoni stresses, which determine the free surface shape during melting and re-solidification. A new SPH approximation of the energy equation is developed to account for the finite thermal boundary conductance and discontinuous temperature field at interfaces between powder particles. A special formulation of three-dimensional RT approach is developed in order to use it together with the SPH method for simulations of laser heating, melting, and melt flow induced by continuous wave (CW) laser irradiation of bulk and powder targets. This RT method does not require explicit interface reconstruction, but it is capable of accurate description of the multiple reflection of laser radiation from the keyhole wall and surfaces of individual powder particles. The DSMC method describes the formation of a vapor jet and its mixing with the background gas. The DSMC method allows one to resolve the gas flow inside the interstitial spaces between powder particles and to account for the non-equilibrium and rarefaction effects, e.g., formation and evolution of non-equilibrium Knudsen layers, which are specific for problems with strong evaporation and condensation. This powder particle solver can be used, e.g., to predict the effect of surface denudation during SLM. All four components of the computational model (SPH, RT, DSMC, and particle trajectory solver) are coupled with each other and integrated into an in-house computational code designed for large-scale parallel simulations. The individual components of this approach can be used either separately from each other or for fully coupled computations.

The computational model developed in this project is used for systematic simulations of (1) deep laser drilling of stainless steel and aluminum targets by stationary CW lasers, (2) prediction of the effective thermal conductivity of metal powders with finite interfacial conductance at interfaces between powder particles, (3) calculation of the effective penetration depth of the laser radiation in a target composed of mono- and polysized powder particles, (4) calculation of the structures of two-dimensional vapor jets induced during SLM of powder and bulk targets, (5) prediction of powder particle entrapping by vapor jets and denudation effect in SLM, (6) single-track simulations of SLM of bulk targets and powder targets, (7) analysis of porosity in the solidified material samples after the SLM. The simulations of the deep laser drilling and SLM processes are performed for a range of laser intensity, spot size, scan speed, and powder particle size.

 The range of applications of the hybrid computational model developed in the present project is not limited by melting and drilling of bulk and powder targets by CW lasers. This numerical model can be applied to study the material removal process and laser-induced plume expansion in pulsed laser ablation. It can be also extended to describe volumetric material removal processes via the phase explosion mechanism that is specific for ablation with high-power nanosecond and ultrashort laser pulses.


Last Modified: 04/30/2020
Modified by: Alexey N Volkov
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project is devoted to the development of a hybrid numerical technique for particle-resolved simulations of the selective laser melting (SLM) process of metal powders and bulk targets based on smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) and application of this technique for theoretical investigation of various pore formation mechanisms in SLM. The key outcome of the project is a three-dimensional computational model and corresponding computer code that account for of all major heat and mass transfer processes in SLM of metal powders. This model includes (1) a multi-phase SPH-based computational model that describes melting and solidification processes, as well hydrodynamics and heat transfer in the molten material flow; (2) ray tracing (RT) approach for modeling of laser radiation propagation and absorption, (3) kinetic model of vapor flow in a background gas, which is implemented in the form of the direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method, and (4) trajectory solver for powder particles. The SPH code for the molten material flow accounts for the recoil and cooling effects of evaporation, as well as the Marangoni stresses, which determine the free surface shape during melting and re-solidification. A new SPH approximation of the energy equation is developed to account for the finite thermal boundary conductance and discontinuous temperature field at interfaces between powder particles. A special formulation of three-dimensional RT approach is developed in order to use it together with the SPH method for simulations of laser heating, melting, and melt flow induced by continuous wave (CW) laser irradiation of bulk and powder targets. This RT method does not require explicit interface reconstruction, but it is capable of accurate description of the multiple reflection of laser radiation from the keyhole wall and surfaces of individual powder particles. The DSMC method describes the formation of a vapor jet and its mixing with the background gas. The DSMC method allows one to resolve the gas flow inside the interstitial spaces between powder particles and to account for the non-equilibrium and rarefaction effects, e.g., formation and evolution of non-equilibrium Knudsen layers, which are specific for problems with strong evaporation and condensation. This powder particle solver can be used, e.g., to predict the effect of surface denudation during SLM. All four components of the computational model (SPH, RT, DSMC, and particle trajectory solver) are coupled with each other and integrated into an in-house computational code designed for large-scale parallel simulations. The computational model developed in this project is used for systematic simulations of (1) deep laser drilling of stainless steel and aluminum targets by stationary CW lasers, (2) prediction of the effective thermal conductivity of metal powders with finite interfacial conductance at interfaces between powder particles, (3) calculation of the effective penetration depth of the laser radiation in a target composed of mono- and polysized powder particles, (4) calculation of the structures of two-dimensional vapor jets induced during SLM of powder and bulk targets, (5) prediction of powder particle entrapping by vapor jets and denudation effect in SLM, (6) single-track simulations of SLM of bulk targets and powder targets, (7) analysis of porosity in the solidified material samples after the SLM.
